I think this was...no, I *know* this was, the hardest Thursday puzzle I've ever seen.  In fact, it not that far off the hardest puzzle I've ever seen.

The theme was astonishingly subtle, in my opinion.  It certainly took me forever, and I really doubted I was ever going to see it.

I think what finally brought it out to me was [Fledge] .  It not being a word, I finally parsed it as a weird combination of FL and edge.

And...I really think 11D, SOO, was at best bordering on unfair.  I don't think I've ever seen letters arbitrarily added to a word.  I know it's supposed to be drawn out, but still.

I suggest you refine the clue for 58D.  Most MBA programs require the GMAT, Graduate Management Admission Test.  Some do accept the GRE, some waive testing especially with job experience. 
Of course when I took the exam in 1975 it was the ATGSB, Admission Test for Graduate Study in Business.

Worth acknowledging the revealer at 1D. I don‚Äôt think it was noted it in Deb‚Äôs column. 

I thought it was a fun, clever puzzle. Congrats Aidan Deshong and Jacob Reed.

The NYT has been euphemising a lot of administrative crime in its coverage these days ("illegal" is not a word that appears in the filter terms for today's roundup of executive actions). To clutch our pearls at the first suggestion of the possibility of a sign of resistance feels like too much timidity. My only hope is that framing the puzzle this way was in service of defending the constructors from possible attack. 

In any case, an enjoyable Thursday, fairly challenging with a clever theme.
